text: [Music]
John McCain offers something very
exciting to the Republican party. That
is he offers a a possibility of reform
and change and transformation. That's
certainly what his career as a
politician has been about. Uh the
downside, the weakness of his candidacy
is that as fervent as he is about the
need for change, the actual content of
the things he offers has always been a
little thin. John McCain has brought his
greatest reforming energy to issues
about which people tend to care very
little. Uh and he also has um a very
weak screen for sorting good ideas from
bad. So in campaign finance for example
um he became tremendously infatuated
with a series of solutions that almost
everyone else who looked at them said
these solutions are going to make worse
all the problems that you say you care
about. And if what you are if what you
are concerned about is a kind of bias of
the political system toward the wealthy
and powerful then McCain fineold is
going to make that problem a lot worse
as indeed it's done. So I I worry I
worry about that. One of the things I
serve very briefly in government and not
in a very important job. But
that short experience made created in me
an even greater respect than I already
felt for the importance of man executive
management uh making uh the ability to
make things work. And those are very
particular human skills and they're not
developed by a career in the Senate. Nor
is the Senate a good place to become a
close student of the consequences both
intended and of the bright ideas that
occur to you.
[Music]
I I don't think that there is a
universal uh I don't think there is such
a thing as leadership in the most
general sense. I mean you see all of
these uh books on the bookshelves that
will say you know leadership secrets of
Jonavar. Now the kind of leadership that
inspired a mob of semiiterate French
soldier peasants uh to fight a foreign
invader 500 years ago. those are not
necessarily the same techniques you use
to organize uh you know the company
softball team. So I I think that there
the kind of I mean John McCain tries to
draw a distinction between leadership
and management but usually what happens
when people talk about leadership is
they end up describing themselves that
all the characteristics they that they
have all the good points they have they
they say that is the essence of
leadership and they set aside all the
things they don't have as as not
important to run the US government
effectively requires tremendous
attention to detail. It requires
tremendous follow-through. The
government is a tremendously resistant
machine. it it's very hard to make it do
the things you want it to do. It's never
enough to set broad goals and it's never
enough to inspire people. You actually
have to manage the beast day by day by
day and to make it go in a direction in
which it's not already going. That
requires not just the exciting qualities
of the orator, the exciting qualities of
the visionary. That requires some of the
very daily humrum qualities of the
manager, of the person who checks that
um that the job is being done, follows
through, holds people accountable.
[Music]
